newsitem.title: LATVIA: REVIEW-ESTONIAN SHARES COOL, LITHUANIA GAINS STEADILY.
newsitem.headline: REVIEW-ESTONIAN SHARES COOL, LITHUANIA GAINS STEADILY.

text.p: Estonian shares caught their breath over the last week as investors reaped profits gained from a recent record-breaking surge while foreign buyers boosted Lithuania's struggling market.
Latvian shares posted more modest gains led by market leader Unibanka.
Analysts say that Estonia should pick up steam again as its gains were backed by better than expected first-half results and raised 1997 profit forecasts.

Lithuania's market remains relatively illiquid but bargain prices, solid results and a good variety of companies have lured foreign investment funds and kindled hopes that a long and brutal correction is over.
ESTONIA
Profit-taking halted Estonia's dizzying bull run in its tracks but dealers dismissed the possibility of bears looming on the horizon.
However, the market's immediate direction was unclear.
"Volumes are down as investors wait for a clear trend, with many waiting for a rise to start," said one dealer.
The Talsi index fell to 403.55 on Thursday from 413.20 the previous Thursday. It had climbed to a record 422.27 on Friday before easing on Monday.
Estonia's market remains by far the most liquid and profitable in the region.
Analysts say its performance reflects the radical economic reforms Estonia has pursued since quitting the Soviet Union in 1991.
LATVIA
Latvian shares crept up slightly amid low liquidity and volumes.
The bourse index rose to 388.15 on Thursday compared to 383.74 the previous week.
Market leader Unibanka dominated trade as usual as it gained to 3.40 lats from 3.31 lats over the week.
Dealers said that the bank's results and expectations that it will maintain a solid performance should translate into further gains, which they hope will pull up the rest of the fledging market.
The bourse has been hard hit by summer and competition from the local debt market, which is where much of the portolio investment in the country goes.
LITHUANIA

Low prices and a relatively wide selection of corporates inticed foreign buyers to Lithuania's market, which dealers said seems to be finally pulling out of a painful correction that set in after shares soared to new highs last January.
That correction has made local investors wary and dealers have pinned their hopes on growing foreign interest to revive the market.
The official list index, which tracks the top five stocks, rose to 1142.23 over the week while the broader group A index climbed to 1977.38 from 1843.41.
"Lately we have noticed bigger foreign buyers coming to the bourse and they tend to invest in official list shares, which pushes the rest of the market up," said one dealer.
Pharmaceutical producer Sanitas grabbed the limelight on Thursday as 50 percent of its shares were sold to foreign investors at 96 litas a piece in a deal worth 33.5 million litas.
"Eight foreign funds and persons bought the shares," Arvydas Jacikevichius, a dealer with Suprema brokerage, told Reuters.
He said that Suprema registered the deal but declined to say which funds or persons were involved.
